entry.title: Re: Plant in Component section of Work Order
entry.content:
When you enter a component in the Component tab of a Work Order in SAP PLM and set the Item Category to 'L' (Stock Item), pressing Enter triggers SAP to automatically populate the Inventory Plant field. This behavior is driven by several configuration and master data dependencies.

The Planning Plant defined in the work order header is used as a reference. SAP assumes that the inventory plant for stock items should match the planning plant unless specified otherwise.

The Plant-specific data in the material master includes default settings for procurement and storage. If the material is extended to the planning plant, SAP uses it as the inventory plant.

Item Category 'L' indicates that the component is a stock item, which must be issued from inventory. SAP needs to know from which plant the stock will be issued, so it defaults to the most logical plant ‚Äî the one associated with the work order.

entry.title: Clean Core Extensibility: Balancing Standardization and Differentiation
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs fast-paced digital landscape, organizations need both agility to innovate and stability to grow sustainably. The key to balancing these goals is a clean digital core ‚Äî an ERP foundation that stays standardized, upgrade-stable, and ready for innovation.
But keeping your core clean doesn‚Äôt mean giving up differentiation. It means being deliberate ‚Äî extending only where it creates true business value and competitive advantage.
This is the essence of Clean Core Extensibility.

The SAP Business Suite brings this vision to life by unifying ERP and line-of-business applications on a common data foundation with embedded AI and SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) for extensibility. Together, these capabilities enable organizations to connect and optimize every function across the enterprise, ensuring that innovation remains upgrade-stable and grounded in reliable, trusted data.

SAP‚Äôs clean core strategy is built on five guiding principles ‚Äî Processes, Extensibility, Data, Integrations, and Operations. In this blog, we focus on the Extensibility principle, exploring how organizations can innovate safely and strategically while maintaining a standardized, upgrade-stable foundation.

The five guiding principles of a clean core

1. Why You Need a Clean Core ‚Äì and the New Extensibility Model

A clean core is the foundation of a modern cloud ERP strategy. It runs on standardized, upgrade-friendly configurations that minimize technical debt and maximize agility.

A clean core ensures:

  • Faster innovation through seamless cloud updates
  • Lower TCO and reduced complexity
  • Business agility through modular, composable extensions

While the clean core provides stability, extensibility defines how you tailor the system to your needs ‚Äî without losing upgradeability. To enable innovation without sacrificing stability, SAP introduced an evolved Extensibility Model ‚Äî separating standard ERP capabilities from custom innovations.

This cloud-first, modular approach allows extensions to live outside the core while connecting seamlessly to it.
It enables organizations to:

  • Build innovations safely on SAP BTP
  • Adopt continuous updates without disruption
  • Keep systems clean, stable, and flexible

The goal is simple: empower business differentiation while maintaining standardization at the core.

2. Strategic Extensibility in Practice: Extending and Applying the Model

Not all extensions add value ‚Äî and not all differentiation requires custom code. True extensibility is strategic: focus on what drives growth, efficiency, or customer experience. Adopt best practices for core business processes, and customize only when it creates measurable advantage.

SAP‚Äôs evolved Extensibility Model emphasizes decoupling extensions from the standard. By leveraging SAP Build, organizations can implement both on-stack (ABAP Cloud) and side-by-side (BTP) extensions, enabling key users and developers to innovate without modifying the SAP core. This approach ensures easier upgrades, better maintainability, and preserves upgrade stability.

Follow SAP‚Äôs extensibility levels to maintain a clean core:

  1. Adopt a BTP-first mindset ‚Äì Use SAP BTP for custom logic, integrations, and innovation.
  2. Prefer Level A/B extensions:
    • Level A: In-app (key-user) extensibility, low-code/no-code
    • Level B: Side-by-side extensions on BTP
  3. Use Level C (classic in-core customization) only when absolutely necessary.
  4. Continuously refactor legacy code ‚Äì Move old customizations out of the core.

This structured approach helps organizations balance standardization and differentiation, ensuring a clean core that is robust, adaptable, and ready for innovation.

Guidance for SAP‚Äôs extensibility levels

3. Measuring Your Clean Core with RISE with SAP Methodology: The Clean Core Measurement Framework

Maintaining a clean core is an ongoing process. The Clean Core Measurement Framework helps organizations assess their governance and maturity, define target actions, and track progress through clean core KPIs.

The Governance and Maturity assessment evaluates the tooling, governance, and know-how required to get and stay clean. It calculates a current score for each clean core dimension and can be performed at any stage ‚Äî before, during, or after transformation. Based on this, customers can define a target score aligned with their strategic goals. These criteria and assessments are fully embedded in the RISE with SAP Methodology.

Clean core KPIs complement this by measuring adherence during both implementation and operations. Derived from system data, these KPIs provide automated, transparent insights ‚Äî fully visible in the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard.

Together, these measurements create visibility and accountability ‚Äî helping organizations stay on track toward a truly clean core.

 4. How to Get Started

Begin your journey toward a Clean Core with Extensibility by reading our White Paper: Clean core extensibility White paper
It outlines a six-step path to achieving a clean core ‚Äî from defining your strategy and analyzing custom code to adopting extension guidelines, establishing governance, and building upgrade-safe extensions.

And don‚Äôt miss the video Achieving Clean Core with the Updated Clean Core Extensibility White Paper for an expert walkthrough of the key concepts and updates.

Start today ‚Äî and turn your clean core into a foundation for continuous innovation.

 5. Customer Example: CAP Group ‚Äì Growth Through Clean Core

CAP Group modernized its ERP by moving custom logic to SAP BTP, achieving:

  • Simplified upgrades and operations
  • Faster innovation delivery
  • Improved scalability and flexibility

Their success shows that a clean core enables innovation and control to coexist ‚Äî driving growth with less complexity. For more details, explore the CAP Group Clean Core Story on SAP.com.

Conclusion

A clean core isn‚Äôt about avoiding customization ‚Äî it‚Äôs about making it count.
By standardizing your foundation, extending only where it drives advantage, and continuously measuring your progress, you build an ERP that‚Äôs agile, efficient, and future-ready.

Balance standardization for efficiency with extensibility for differentiation ‚Äî that‚Äôs the essence of a clean core.

entry.title: UI.HEADERINFO: TypeNamePlural is mandatory
entry.content:
Hi ABAP/Fiori Devs,

I am facing a recurring issue ABAP Repository Objects Generator on BTP ABAP Environment / Fiori Tools List report wizard.  I have a manual fix for that, but there might be a trick to prevent this instructing SAP code generators. Nevertheless, You can use the below manual fix as well.

Using the generated UI V4 service in the List Report template in Business Application Studio I get metadata.xml issues. It is complaining about missing annotations.
The generated CDS metadata extension does not contain typeName and typeNamePlural annotations by default, so I added them manually.

.headerInfo: { title: { type: #STANDARD, value: 'MaterialID' },
                  description: { type: #STANDARD, value: 'MaterialName' },
                  typeName: 'Material',
                  typeNamePlural: 'Materials' }

It fixes the issue after refreshing the metadata in BAS.

I wonder someone knows the trick to prevent this issue without manual post-processing. Please do not hesitate to share it here üññ.
Thank You, Attila

entry.title: Web service errors 403 and 401 after upgrade to SAP S/4HANA 2023 SP03 (Kernel 793, PL 300)
entry.content:
We are currently testing our SAP system after upgrading to SAP S/4HANA 2023 SP03 (kernel version 793, patch level 300) .

After the update, we encountered issues with incoming web service calls :

  • External systems accessing SAP using a server certificate receive:
    403 Forbidden - Certificate required

  • When calling the same web service using a client certificate, we get:
    401 Unauthorized

At the same time, the SAP system can successfully call these external systems (outbound communication is working properly).

Our configuration:

  • icm/HTTPS/verify_client = 1 (verified via SMICM)

  • Certificates are imported mutually and trusted on both sides

  • The same integration scenario worked correctly in SAP S/4HANA 2021

Has anyone encountered this behavior after upgrading to S/4HANA 2023?
Any suggestions on what might have changed in the ICM/SSL behavior or SICF authentication handling?

entry.title: Re: Dynamic Threshold-Based Background Color for SAC Nume...
entry.content:
Hi @Fiona_,

we usually solve this issue by not changing the overall background color, since this is quite slow as it will include an OnResultChanged coding which not only needs to read the current value but also changes the CSS style of the numeric point. The slow part here is the coding for getting the current value (usually results in https request to the backend).

We therefore add one or more variances to the KPI like shown below:

So although the background is not red, it¬¥s already really quick to anticipate, if the KPI is "good" or "bad".

If you really need to change the background color, the steps with OnResultChanged are:

  1. Get the (new) value currently visible
  2. Compare that value with you good/bad/neutral/... threshold
  3. Based on the threshold, set the CSS Style using setCssClass

Upfront you oviously need to define different CSS classes for good/bad/neutral/...

Best regards,
Denis

entry.title: How to generate the relative URL in the SAP SAC.
entry.content:
Mostly we need url to download the excel template or some functional document from the story so we can download by click on the button, but we are facing an issue when we move the file or document from one system to another system at that time we face an issue to change the URL of the file which point out to the Quality or development system instead of production.

To overcome the above issue we can use a relative url so no need to change the URL again and again base on the tenant we are using it will auto adjust the URL

 

Below are the step we need to follow to generate the relative URL for excel file type

On page select button click event  we need to write a below code

var relative_url = NavigationUtils.createApplicationUrl(Application.getInfo().id);

var fileid = "D5920047F7326A3F92C872224F5E12E";

NavigationUtils.openUrl(relative_url.slice(0, relative_url.lastIndexOf("/sap/fpa/ui/")+12)+"#view_id=contentLib;resourceId="+fileid+";resourceType=FILE",true);

 

We can use the code to open any folder in SAC system  base on the system login

Below is the sample code

var relative_url = NavigationUtils.createApplicationUrl(Application.getInfo().id);

var folder_id = ‚ÄúAB901784C89412AB6FB0FA5679FB7ED1‚Äù

NavigationUtils.openUrl(relative_url.slice(0, relative_url.lastIndexOf("/sap/fpa/ui/")+12).concat("app.html#/files&/f/myfiles/‚Äù+folder_id),true);

 

Step to get the fileid

Select the file and click on the share inside the share panel you will find url of file inside that you can find the resource ID.

Step to get the folder_id

Open the folder for which you need to create the URL in SAC in the URL of browser you will find the 32 digit code

entry.title: How To Break Into Consulting: A Step-by Step Guide For Aspirants
entry.content:
Consulting has become one of the most dynamic and high-impact careers for early-career talents. Whether it‚Äôs managing a merger or supporting digital transformation, consultants work across many industries to deliver value, solve problems, and drive change. 

But here's the big question: How do you break into consulting, especially if you're starting your career? 

We spoke with Ali Al Hashim, a Business Analyst at Deloitte and a graduate of the SAP Young Professionals' program, to explore what worked for him and how aspiring consultants can start strong.

1. Understand What Consulting Really Is 

Consulting is all about problem-solving, usually in a fast-paced, client-facing environment. Consultants are brought in when companies need to make strategic decisions, improve performance, or implement new systems. 

There are different types of consulting roles: 

  • Management consulting ‚Äì strategy, operations, organizational design
  • Technology consulting ‚Äì ERP systems (like SAP), AI (such as Joule), cloud, and analytics
  • Financial and compliance consulting ‚Äì audits, regulations, risk
  • Digital transformation consulting ‚Äì cloud migrations, business change initiatives
  • Each type requires a different blend of business understanding, technical insight, and strong communication skills

Each area requires a different blend of business knowledge, technical skills, and communication abilities.

2. Build the Right Skillset. It's Not Just About Your Degree! 

You don‚Äôt need to have a specific degree to get into the field, but consulting companies are often looking for people who demonstrate analytical thinking, communication skills, and business understanding. 

‚ÄúConsulting is more about how you think and how fast you can learn new things. If you stay curious and open, you can build a great career even if you start from a totally different background.‚Äù-  Ali Al Hashim, Business Analyst in Deloitte (BTP- SAP Consulting) 

Here are some high-value skills you can start working on now: 

  • Analytical thinking and problem-solving (using frameworks like SWOT or Porter's Five Forces) 
  • Structured communication (especially using Excel and PowerPoint) 
  • Project management basics (knowing the basics of agile, waterfall, or PM tools) 
  • Cross-functional teamwork with other business areas such as Finance, HR, Logistics, among others. 
  • Storytelling with data (Learn how to interpret dashboards, structure data narratives, and make recommendations that align with business goals. Tools like SAP Analytics Cloud, Power BI, or Tableau are worth exploring

Adding relevant courses or certifications might give you extra points as well, and you can build these skills through online courses, volunteering, university projects, or certifications. 

3. Preparing for interviews 

Consulting interviews often involve case studies, behavioral questions, and problem-solving exercises. Therefore, be ready for:  

  • Case interviews ‚Äì solve a business problem out loud  
  • Behavioral questions ‚Äì show self-awareness and collaboration 
  • Problem-solving exercises ‚Äì think under pressure, structure your approach 

üí°Pro tip: Practice your pitch. Know how to tell your story and explain why you're interested in consulting 

4. Choose Your Entry Point Wisely 

While many consultants start in business roles (e.g., Finance, HR, or Strategy) and transition into consulting later, others take another route by joining specialized programs like the SAP Young Professionals, designed for fresh graduates. The program offers world-class training on the latest, in-demand SAP solutions, helping participants kickstart their careers in tech consulting with confidence. 

Ali Al Hashim's Experience in the SAP Young Professionals program

‚ÄúJoining the SAP Young Professionals program really opened my eyes to the fact that consulting is not only for people who already have big experience or come from a business background. It‚Äôs for anyone who has the passion to learn, ask questions, and connect the technology and business sides. We live in the age of technology, and it‚Äôs changing so fast that sometimes you feel behind, but that‚Äôs okay, because consulting teaches you to keep learning and move forward. For me, this program helped me believe more in my skills and that it‚Äôs not about being perfect, it‚Äôs about growing with every project you do.‚Äù - Ali Al Hashim, Business Analyst in Deloitte (BTP- SAP Consulting)

Interested in joining? üëâ Visit the Digital Skills Center for more information.  

Availability of our programs may vary by country. Please keep an eye on the website as new positions will open in different countries for the 2026 cohorts.

entry.title: Handling contractor over-hours and SES exceeding PO quantity in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

we are using SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud with external contractors who record their working hours through the Manage My Timesheet application. Each approved timesheet entry automatically creates a Service Entry Sheet, and supplier invoices are then matched to the related purchase order.

In practice, contractors sometimes record more hours than the purchase order quantity allows. These additional hours must remain visible for our customer project billing, as we invoice clients based on all recorded time. However, these extra hours should not create additional Service Entry Sheets or cost postings for vendor invoicing beyond the approved purchase order quantity.

As a result, we encounter several issues:

  • The total service quantity in SES exceeds the ordered amount.

  • A large number of micro-SES entries are created, which makes invoice matching and reconciliation very time-consuming.

  • The excess SES remain posted to cost accounts and require manual clearing.

  • This slows down supplier invoice processing and increases administrative workload.

We would like to know if there is a supported configuration or standard process in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud that would allow contractors to record all hours in Manage My Timesheet for customer project billing, while limiting SES creation and cost postings for vendor invoicing to the approved purchase order quantity ‚Äî keeping any excess hours visible only for reporting purposes without accounting impact.

Any guidance, best practices, or SAP Notes addressing this scenario would be very much appreciated.

Thank you!

Barbora

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit: Adapt the XML file to your business needs
entry.content:
When using the staging approach for your data migration, you often face the challenge that the provided XML file contains sheets and columns within the sheets that are not relevant for your business needs.

Did you know that it is possible to adjust the XML files easily?

However, before I go to the possible options, note that you must be careful when deleting, as any change can corrupt the XML structure. There is also no guarantee that such a tailored XML file can still be used after upgrading to a higher release.

After creating a migration project in the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit using the Migrate Your Data app select Download Template in Action for a specific migration object and choose File Type ‚Üí XML file.

Note 

The description below is for Microsoft Excel. The procedure may differ when using another spreadsheet program than Microsoft Excel.

Option 1: Delete a non-mandatory sheet

Open the downloaded file and choose Enable Editing button. Select a non-mandatory sheet you want to delete ‚Äì choose the context menu by clicking on your mouse and choose "Delete".

 Confirm on the follow up pop-up you want to delete.

Proceed in this way with all the non-mandatory sheets that you want to delete.

Note

You can only delete non-mandatory sheets and delete sheets even though the worksheet contains mandatory columns. This is because there is no need to fill the mandatory columns in the sheet with data if the sheet itself is not relevant for your project.

Option 2:  Delete a non-mandatory column within a sheet

First, you need to unprotect the sheet. So, you need to select a sheet where you want to delete one column or more columns ‚Äì choose the context menu by clicking right on your mouse and select ‚ÄúUnprotect Sheet‚Äù.

Select the column(s) you want to delete ‚Äì in my example all columns for Tax Calculation Brazil. Choose "Delete".

Note

Alternatively, you can go to File ‚Üí Info ‚Üí Protect Workbook area and click on Unprotect for the sheets you want to make changes on.

Save your changes. You can now fill your XML file as usual and load the data into the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit.

When you upload your data, the tool informs you that the Validation Completed with Warnings.  

To be able to view the messages, choose "Show Messages" you get a list of all messages occurred during Validation.

In this case, warnings are displayed because the fields deleted in the previous steps are missing from the sheet. 

 To load the data into the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit select your file and transfer the data via Actions ‚Üí Transfer Data to Staging Tables.

 The instances will be loaded into the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit staging tables.

You can now proceed with your data migration steps as usual.

 Using CSV files

Like the XML file, you can easily tailor your CSV files  as you only need to use the files for the structures and fields you want to process. Just provide the files for mandatory structures and the structures you need. Within the files you must also only provide the mandatory fields and the fields you need. All the other fields you can remove.  A CSV file has much less administrative data than an XML file. The 100 MB limit is the same, but with tailored CSV files the http-protocol related size limit is not reached that fast as using XML files.

entry.title: Assembly Scrap | SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I‚Äôm currently working in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud ERP, and I have a question regarding how Assembly Scrap affects both production quantity and cost estimation.

When I enter an assembly scrap percentage in the Material Master (MRP 1 view), I expect the system to calculate the correct production quantity and adjust the cost estimate accordingly.

Example

Customer order: 1,000 good pieces (yield)
Standard price: 2 USD per piece (without assembly scrap)
Assembly Scrap = 50%

Expected system behavior:

System should plan 2,000 pieces to produce 1,000 good ones
The actual cost per piece should increase to 4 USD (including scrap)

However, in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the system only plans for 1,500 pieces, and the actual cost becomes 3 USD per piece, meaning it only considers 33% scrap, not 50%.

Questions

Why does the system behave like this?
Is there a way to make the system fully reflect 50% assembly scrap in both production planning (MRP) and product costing (CK11N)?
Do I need to adjust configuration or costing lot-size parameters for this to work as expected?

Any insights or examples from your experience would be greatly appreciated!
Best regards,
Antonio

entry.title: Re: Dynamic Threshold-Based Background Color for SAC Nume...
entry.content:
@Fiona_ as mentioned by @DenisT , you can try the below workaround.

Create a custom CSS for positive and negative values defining the background colour.

.positive .sap-custom-chart-widget {
    background-color: #e6f9e6 ; /* Light green background */
    border: 1px solid #d1d5db; /* Subtle border */
    border-radius: 12px; /* Rounded corners */
    box-shadow: 0 4px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1); /* Soft shadow */
    opacity: 1; /* Fully visible */
}
.negative .sap-custom-chart-widget {
    background-color: #fde8e8 ; /* Light red background */
    border: 1px solid #d1d5db; /* Subtle border */
    border-radius: 12px; /* Rounded corners */
    box-shadow: 0 4px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1); /* Soft shadow */
    opacity: 1; /* Fully visible */
}

use the below script for onresultchanged event of your numeric point chart to change the CSS class based on result.

// Fetch data cell from the Numeric point chart
var result = Chart_1.getDataSource().getResultSet([{"M1_GL_ACCOUNT":"[M1_GL_ACCOUNT].[parentId].&[Units Sold]"}]); // get the value of your numeric data point.

var obj = result[0];

for (var item in obj)
	{
		var test = obj[item].rawValue;
	}
//Evaluate the value and assign a CSS style

var val = ConvertUtils.stringToInteger(test);

if (val > 100000){
		Chart_1.setCssClass("positive");
	} 
else if(val < 100000){
		Chart_1.setCssClass("negative");
	}
else{
	Chart_1.setCssClass("");
}

Hello Kunkumasudharshan Radhakrishnan,

do you want to display the amount along with the currency symbol is that your requirement? If yes, then you can use scripting language on the amount field of adobe form layout and then write something like below. With this code your amount field will look from 100.00 -> $ 100.00 

 var currKey = this.parent.CurrKey.rawValue;
 
 if ( currKey == 'EUR' ){
      this.format.picture.value = "num{'‚Ç¨' z,zzz,zzz,zz9.99}", this.rawValue;

 else {
      this.format.picture.value = "num{z,zzz,zzz,zz9.99}", this.rawValue;
 }

entry.title: Join Our CEI: Co-innovate the Future of AI-Powered Risk Assessment in APM
entry.content:
AI-Assisted Draft Risk Assessments in SAP Asset Performance Management

We invite you to join our latest SAP Customer Engagement Initiative (CEI) focused on using AI to detect unassessed assets and automatically propose draft risk assessments ‚Äî an exciting innovation in SAP Asset Performance Management (APM).

We‚Äôre looking for reliability engineers, asset managers, and maintenance leads to co-innovate with us and help shape intelligent automation for risk assessment. This is a great opportunity for Customers and Partners to gain early insights into product developments and actively collaborate with SAP teams to shape the future of SAP solutions.

Registration is open until November 15, 2025. Sign up today!

Why This Matters

Reliability engineers today spend valuable time manually tracking new technical objects synced from Cloud ERP into APM and verifying whether they already have matching risk assessments. This process is manual, time-consuming, and prone to inconsistencies.

Through this CEI, we aim to leverage AI-driven automation to:

  • Detect technical objects without existing risk assessments.
  • Propose draft assessments based on historical data and similar asset patterns.
  • Reduce manual effort and potential human error.
  • Improve coverage and consistency across your asset base.

Together, we‚Äôll define a more efficient approach to risk assessment management in APM.

What You‚Äôll Help Define

You‚Äôll collaborate with the APM Product Management team to explore:

  • Intelligent detection and AI-based proposal logic.
  • Seamless integration with APM and Cloud ERP.
  • User-friendly workflows for reviewing and refining AI drafts.
  • Transparent explainability for trust and auditability.

What to Expect

  • Initial Call: Project goals and roadmap (Dec 10, 2025)
  • Workshops / Site Visits: Depending on availability
  • Video Conferences: Manageable intervals for feedback and alignment
  • Usability and Prototype Testing: Early look at concepts in action
  • Closing Call: Wrap-up and next steps

Estimated effort: 4‚Äì6 hours per month

Who Can Join

  • Target Users: Reliability Engineers focused on risk assessments ‚Äî responsible for identifying, assessing, and mitigating risks to ensure asset safety, uptime, and performance.
  • Regions: APJ, EMEA, and Americas
  • Company Size: Mid-size to large enterprises
  • Partners: Welcome to join, especially those with asset management expertise.

Why Participate

By joining, you‚Äôll:

  • Influence the design of AI-enabled risk assessment features in APM.
  • Contribute your practical experience to shape real-world use cases.
  • Test early prototypes and collaborate directly with SAP experts.

Registration is open until November 15,
Sign up now: Identify Unassessed Assets and Auto-Propose Draft Risk Assessments Using AI Agent

For more information about the broader CEI see Third Time's a Charm: SAP Customer Engagement Initiative 2025 Cycle 3 Now Live!

Your expertise makes the difference.
We look forward to co-innovating with you!

Contact Ganesh Nayak (ganesh.nayak@sap.com) for more details.

I was trying out flexible column tutorial and was facing the same issue. Below code worked for me

      onListItemPress: function (oEvent) {
        // Get the FlexibleColumnLayout and set to two-column layout
        var oAppView = this.getOwnerComponent().getRootControl();
        var oFCL = oAppView.byId("app");

          if (oDetailView) {
            oDetailView.setBindingContext(oBindingContext);
          }
        }
      }

entry.title: Re: Multiple Questions Regarding SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud...
entry.content:
Good day @byd 

Thank you for your question.

Let us in summary address each question step by step:

Answer to Question 1:

Here are references to support you on this: Advanced Payment Management, Map Format Data for Advanced Payment Management

Blogs: Payments and Bank Communication in S/4HANA Cloud, Bank Integration with SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity (16R)

In summary, yes, ISO 20022 files are supported natively in public cloud. You can use 1EG and 4MT (16R would be an option as well) scope items to manage it. In both 1EG and 4MT you can generate the ISO 20022 file and download it through Manage Automatic Payments or Map Format Data for Advanced Payment Management.

Manage Automatic Payments (here you can create or define your pararmeters)

Map Format Data for Advanced Payment Management (here you can format your data mappings)

 

Answer to Question 2:

To summarise, there is no single predefined COGM Statement report. However, you can build it from the standard components such as:

  • Standard Costing apps which cover Material Cost Estimate and Cost Component Split.

  • Universal Journal (GL) for actuals.
  • SAP Analytics Cloud for formatted reporting or story views.

Based on my knowledge a lot of Japanese manufacturers use SAC stories or Custom Analytical Queries to assemble a COGM style report.

 

Answer to Question 3:

Here are references to support you on this: TRM, Transaction Management Localization for Japan, Financial Statement Versions, Define Financial Statement Versions,  Retail Localization for Japan

To summarise, yes, the public cloud delivers localized financial statement versions for Japan and it supports all legal statements under the Japanese GAAP. This is typically set up as:

  • Balance Sheet & Profit/Loss through localized financial statement versions.
  • Using standard Finance apps to set up Journal Entries & General Ledger.
  • Output Management helps you handle all outputs for PDF or Excel formats.

 

Answer to Question 4:

Here are references to support you on this: How to Extend a Custom Form Template for Billing Output with Standard Fields, Date Determination in Sales

a. To summarise, its best practice to use the standard field Service Rendered Date also known as the Performance Date at billing item level. It represents the actual transaction date for your tax and accrual purposes. If it is not displayed on the form, consider using the Custom Fields & Logic app (Form Templates for Billing) to extend your billing output template.
b. Regarding Invoice PDF Storage and Retrieval, yes, invoice PDFs that are generated through Output Management are stored automatically in the system. You can view or re-download them from the billing document‚Äôs Output Items tab.

Here are references to support you on this: Output Management for Sales Documents and Billing Process Documents, Attachment Service, Document Storage, SAP Information Lifecycle Management

If you are considering long-term storage, I advice you use the Attachment Service or Information Lifecycle Management for archiving.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

 

Thank you in advance for any additional insights or implementation tips from those who have set up similar processes in Japan.

entry.title: Re: Assistance with Updating Outbound Delivery Multiple I...
entry.content:
To update custom fields for multiple item lines in an Outbound Delivery in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, you must ensure that each item line is individually addressed in the payload and that the custom fields are correctly mapped to the item-level extension structure. The issue you're facing‚Äîonly the first item updating‚Äîlikely stems from incorrect payload structure or binding logic.

Below would be some of the key considerations for updating multiple item lines

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, custom fields created via Custom Fields and Logic app must be explicitly bound to the item-level business context, such as Delivery Item & Purchase Order Item. If your custom fields are bound only to the header or a single item property, they won‚Äôt apply to multiple items.

Your payload must include distinct entries for each item, and each entry must contain its own set of custom fields. Ensure that the item-level extension fields (e.g., YY1_*_PDI) are nested correctly under each item node.

When using the Outbound Delivery API, confirm that you're calling the correct PATCH or PUT method for item-level updates. Some APIs may default to updating only the first item unless the payload explicitly loops through all items.

entry.title: 2511 - Dynamic Quote Item Custom Field Access Control unexpected behavior
entry.content:
When using the SetColumnAccessLevel method with the Hidden option, only the fields in that column get "hidden" (they show up blank), but the column is still visible on the quote. This is not the desired behavior as the column should disappear from the quote if all of its fields are hidden.

--- Steps to Reproduce ---

  1. Open the Quote Item Custom Fields Access Permission scripting window under Field Editability.
  2. Enter the code below, replacing the quote item custom field name of your choosing and save.
  3. Open a quote where your chosen custom field was previously visible.
  4. Note that the column is still visible on the quote.

 

Code:

from Scripting.Quote import QuoteFieldAccessLevel

QuoteFieldAccessContext.SetColumnAccessLevel('my_quote_item_custom_field', QuoteFieldAccessLevel.Hidden)

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: 2511 - Dynamic Quote Item Custom Field Access Control...
entry.content:
By using the hidden option, we can just hide the values, and the column won't be removed if it's empty.

The column can only be managed through the quote layout.

As the help document Dynamic Access Control for Quote Item Custom Fields | SAP Help Portal states, "Accessing Quote Item Custom Fields via scripting lets you dynamically set permissions for these fields. You can control their editability, read-only status, and visibility.

entry.title: Oversized Requirements? Here's how to fix them.
entry.content:
Getting requirement sizing right is an important but less obvious driver of predictable SAP project delivery. It is the art of making requirements neither too big nor too small. This may sound like a detail, but it shapes everything that follows: how releases are planned, how work is owned, and how testing stays traceable. After formulation and classification standards, it is another dimension to properly creating requirements.

Why requirements granularity is important?

Granularity defines how big or small a requirement should be so that it can be delivered, tested, and accepted within a single delivery or release cycle.

On one hand, if requirements are too large, their delivery will stretch across waves. This means that one requirement will not be fully completed and fully tested within one Wave release. That breaks the flow of delivery and the traceability of results.

On the other hand, if requirements are too small, the requirements backlog swells with too many tiny items which adds administration effort and slows down the work.

The golden rule

SAP Activate recommends sizing requirements so they can be fully delivered and tested within a single Wave and inside one Work Package. This makes tracking progress from requirement through configuration to test case much easier.

To keep delivery predictable, adopt a simple rule: One Requirement ‚Üí One Work Package ‚Üí One Test Case ‚Üí One Wave

 Decomposition and Grouping

Use early Explore workshops for iterative refinement which is continuously splitting or regrouping requirements as delivery planning evolves.

If a requirement is too large, decompose it into smaller, independent, testable sub-requirements. Each should deliver a clear, standalone piece of value that can be tested independently. They still can be associated with each other in the same test plan.

If a requirement is too small, group it with other closely related requirements and reformulate them into one coherent requirement delivered as one work package.

The effort pays off: proper sizing makes ownership clear, simpler planning, and complete test traceability from requirement to configuration and testing results.

Iterative refinement

Skipping granularity refinement often leaves oversized requirements that may span two waves. This reduces transparency, complicates test coverage, and makes progress reporting unreliable. Right-sized requirements make governance measurable: every item in the backlog has a clear boundary, a single owner, and a defined success criteria.

Iterative refinement

Skipping granularity refinement often leaves oversized requirements that may span two waves. This reduces transparency, complicates test coverage, and makes progress reporting unreliable. Right-sized requirements make governance measurable: every item in the backlog has a clear boundary, a single owner, and a defined success criteria.

Jira practice

Granularity can be managed directly in Jira by defining clear parent‚Äìchild relationships between Requirements and their Deliverables. This approach keeps ownership, scheduling, and testing transparent.

  • Create each main Requirement as a standard level work item

  • In case of need for a decomposition, add sub-task level work items called Sub-Requirements underneath.

  • Map each Requirement or Sub-Requirement to a single Work Package that will be scheduled in one Wave to preserve traceability.

  • Link every requirement to the corresponding Jira Xray Test Cases that verify acceptance and completion.

 You can visualize the hierarchy using a Jira app such as Structure, to display dependencies and delivery scope clearly

 What‚Äôs in it for you?

Requirements granularity may sound like a technical detail, but in SAP projects it‚Äôs one of the strongest predictors of delivery stability. In simple terms, your project scheduling will be much more reliable.

So, next time before you approve a requirement in your backlog, ask: "Will this fit into one Wave, in one Work Package, tested by one Test Case?" If yes, go to the next requirement.

If you have found this article helpful, please leave me a Kudo on top of this page. This will encourage me to write more articles in SAP Community. Thank you!

Want to learn more about managing SAP projects in Jira?

Follow me to get notified about new articles on managing SAP projects and how Jira can support your S/4HANA transformation.

About author

Bogdan G√≥rka works as Atlassian Solution Architect and SAP Project Governance Consultant. Creator of R2D ALM for Jira, independent Atlassian consultant, and founder of PMBG.EU.

entry.title: Using Joule Studio Custom AI Agents to Query Case Status from ServiceNow
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I'm exploring a use-case with custom Joule Agents, and wondering if anyone has tried something similar yet with ServiceNow (preferably) or other case systems?

The scenario I'm after: An employee is logged into SuccessFactors and asks Joule something like ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the status of my case (ref: xxxxx)?‚Äù

The aim is for Joule to retrieve the case details from ServiceNow and return the update directly in the Joule chat, without the employee needing to switch systems (steps listed below).

  1. Use the employee's current SuccessFactors user context
  2. Call ServiceNow to get case/ticket status/details for that employee only
  3. Return the result directly in the Joule chat
  4. Uses the SAP Integration Suite or ServiceNow REST API exposed as a Skill

We already use the ServiceNow IntegrationHub SuccessFactors Spoke, and we maintain a shared user identifier between the systems, so user identity matching is already in place. I‚Äôd be interested to know if this can be leveraged alongside the Joule Agent.

Also, which approach would be recommended:

  • Joule ‚Üí SAP Integration Suite ‚Üí ServiceNow
  • Joule ‚Üí ServiceNow REST API directly as a skill

Regards,

Dauied Medhanie

entry.title: Suggestion for Improvement in Replication Flow Validation
entry.content:
I'd like to propose an enhancement to the Replication Flow behavior when working with CDS Views.

Imagine I'm importing data from a CDS View that contains 5 columns. In the CDS View selection screen, I can see both the technical names and the business descriptions of each column:

 

Technical Name Description / Business Name
Col1Key
Col2Creation Date
Col3Name of Material
Col4Name of Material
Col5Name of Material

When I create a Replication Flow without a Projection, everything works smoothly.

However, if I add a Projection‚Äîperhaps to include an extra column or to adjust the content of existing columns‚Äîthe interface throws errors due to duplicate column descriptions. Specifically, columns 3, 4, and 5 all share the same description: Name of Material. To resolve this, I‚Äôm forced to manually rename the descriptions to something like Name of Material 1, Name of Material 2, etc.

This seems unnecessary. The validation should focus on technical names, not business descriptions, since the technical names are unique and sufficient for identifying columns.

Suggestion:
Skip validation on column descriptions/business names during Projection. Only validate technical names to avoid unnecessary manual adjustments and improve usability.

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud_Payment Media file contains no data
entry.content:
Good day @nguyenthuthao125832 

Thank you for your question.

Here are references to guide you

Available Payment Medium Formats for Contract Accounting, Configuring Payment Medium Formats

Payment Medium Format, Creating Custom Payment Medium Formats, Payment Medium Creation

Processing Payment Files, Monitor Payments

To summarise, a blank payment file when you use public cloud typically points to missing mappings or unlinked configurations rather than a system error. Consider verifying your payment format assignment, DMEE mapping, and payment run output. This should help you resolve the issue without custom development.

If you are cloning a payment medium format (e.g., /JP_ZENGINKYO √†ZENGINKYO_CUSTOM), you should always consider the best practice to:

  • Use ‚ÄúCopy From Standard‚Äù in Manage Payments Formats.
  • Maintain all root node attributes.
  • Re-link it in the payment method configuration.
  • Re-activate and test through Manage Automatic Payments.
  • Review specific error generated to guide troubleshooting.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.content:
@rodrigovieirait  Ola;

Agrade√ßo o detalhamento compartilhado sobre o cen√°rio enfrentado pela equipe de Compras em rela√ß√£o ao bloqueio do campo ‚ÄúOrigem do Material‚Äù nas transa√ß√µes ME21N, ME22N, ME51N e ME52N, decorrente da ativa√ß√£o da avalia√ß√£o dividida (Split Valuation) no SAP S/4HANA.

De fato, conforme definido na configura√ß√£o de Valuation & Account Assignment, quando a avalia√ß√£o dividida est√° ativa, o controle de valoriza√ß√£o do material passa a ser feito por tipo de avalia√ß√£o e classe de valoriza√ß√£o.
Esse mecanismo impacta diretamente a determina√ß√£o autom√°tica de contas (Automatic Account Determination ‚Äì AAD), pois a contabiliza√ß√£o √© direcionada com base em par√¢metros fixos ‚Äî Valuation Area, Valuation Class, Account Category Reference e Transaction Key ‚Äî que se tornam dependentes do tipo de avalia√ß√£o configurado.

Por essa raz√£o, o SAP bloqueia a edi√ß√£o manual de campos que poderiam alterar a l√≥gica cont√°bil associada ao material, como √© o caso do c√≥digo de origem, j√° que sua varia√ß√£o poderia gerar inconsist√™ncias nos lan√ßamentos autom√°ticos de G/L Accounts durante o processo de Goods Movement ou Invoice Posting.

Entendemos, entretanto, que no contexto brasileiro a legisla√ß√£o fiscal exige flexibilidade para indicar o c√≥digo de origem do material (0 a 9) conforme o fornecedor e a composi√ß√£o do produto.
Nesse sentido, a sugest√£o apresentada ‚Äî permitir a edi√ß√£o desse campo nas transa√ß√µes de Compras mesmo com Split Valuation ativo ‚Äî representa uma melhoria relevante para a ader√™ncia do SAP √†s pr√°ticas locais.

Como pr√≥ximos passos, recomendamos:

  1. Registrar oficialmente o caso via SAP Customer Influence Program, classificando como Localization Requirement ‚Äì Brazil.

  2. Anexar evid√™ncias do impacto no processo de Aquisi√ß√£o e Contabiliza√ß√£o, conforme descrito, demonstrando o desalinhamento entre o controle t√©cnico do SAP e a exig√™ncia legal nacional.

  3. Validar alternativas tempor√°rias, como:

    • Utilizar tipos de avalia√ß√£o diferenciados por origem de material (quando aplic√°vel);

    • Criar campos Z (custom fields) no cabe√ßalho do pedido de compra para registrar a origem fiscal sem interferir na l√≥gica cont√°bil do material;

    • Avaliar, junto √† consultoria, o impacto dessa customiza√ß√£o na determina√ß√£o autom√°tica de contas (AAD) e nas chaves cont√°beis GBB, BSX, WRX e PRD.

Ressalto que qualquer altera√ß√£o direta via SHD0 ou enhancement que permita editar campos bloqueados por design SAP deve ser cuidadosamente analisada, pois pode comprometer a integridade da Automatic Account Determination e gerar diverg√™ncias entre MM e FI.

tive a oportunidade de estruturar todo o ambiente do zero, incluindo:

  • Cria√ß√£o de tr√™s companhias, sendo duas com fluxos intercompany totalmente integrados;

  • Configura√ß√£o completa de materiais, classes de valoriza√ß√£o e tipos de avalia√ß√£o;

  • Parametriza√ß√£o da Automatic Account Determination (AAD) e integra√ß√£o MM‚ÄìFI, garantindo a determina√ß√£o correta das contas cont√°beis (BSX, WRX, GBB, PRD).

 

Atenciosamente,
Aluizio Silva

entry.title: Taking Control of Clean Core: When to Use Project Kernseife in addition to Standard SAP Tools
entry.content:
TL;DR

Measuring SAP Clean Core involves a choice:

  • As a RISE with SAP customer, you can benefit from the out-of-the-box standard approach with SAP Cloud ALM. The RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard provides you with a high-level standardized view with minimal effort.
  • Or you can choose an open-source, highly flexible, and customizable approach with Project Kernseife. You get custom classification to create actionable insights, but it requires ownership and additional effort.

This article will help you decide which path is right for your team's Clean Core journey.

How the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard measures Clean Core

SAP's answer on how to measure clean core is based on two standard tools: The ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC) (and its newly released checks as from SAP Note 3565942) and the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard in SAP Cloud ALM.

The process begins with the ATC, which analyzes your custom code against a well-defined set of rules. The key to this analysis is the classification of your custom extensions based on the official release status of the standard SAP objects they utilize. This release information is transparently published by SAP in the Cloudification Repository (Viewer).

As described in more detail in the Clean Core Extensibility Whitepaper (see chapter 3.3), the ATC assigns your extension a level based on the most critical SAP object it utilizes:

  • Level A - For extensions using only stable, released objects, ensuring maximum upgrade security.
  • Level B - For extensions whose most critical dependency is a classic API like a BAPI or classic technical frameworks.
  • Level C - For extensions touching any unreleased, internal SAP objects.
  • Level D - For extensions using objects that are explicitly not recommended.

The results of this structured analysis can then be uploaded to SAP Cloud ALM, populating the Clean Core Extensibility KPIs in the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard. Recently, the dashboard was enhanced with a display of the Clean Core  Levels. This gives organizations a high-level, standardized view of their extensibility landscape, which is perfect for assessing their current situation and tracking progress. For the near future (Q1/2026) it is moreover planned to offer a deep dive dashboard that provides further details about the results.

What is "Project Kernseife"?

Project Kernseife is an open-source custom ATC Check for ABAP systems that enables you to flexibly score the usage of SAP objects in your system, e.g. to score the technical debt regarding clean core based on a custom, adjustable classification. More details on the parts and approach can be found in the blog "Project Kernseife - improving the measurement of Clean Core in ABAP".

Why Project Kernseife and its custom classification can be a Game-Changer for Clean Core Governance

Advantage 1: Fine-Tune SAP's Rules & Reduce "False Positives"

While SAP delivers thousands of released and classic APIs, it might still be not the perfect fit for your individual project and scope. Kernseife allows you to re-classify objects as "acceptable for your project", dramatically reducing noise and the need for mass ATC exemptions. Let's look into two different scenarios, to show you the benefits of custom classification:

Example 1: Stricter governance for direct table read

Within the standard classification, a direct read with a SELECT from any SAP table is considered as "Level C", which leads to warnings in ABAP Test Cockpit. In your project, you want to enforce the usage of ABAP cloud, you maybe have (see next point) identified many successor objects (custom and standard) and want to push developers to the successors objects (e.g., famous I_Product instead of MARA) by showing these as an error.
Remark: In standard ATC, you can adjust the priority of a check message in general (for example "Reading from DDIC database tables or DDIC table views is not recommended (successor available)", but not based on specific SAP objects you refer to.

Example 2: Need for usage of "internal object"

Now let's imagine you are working in a "clean core" project, but you need to extend processes around the Outbound Delivery Orders in EWM. After talking to experts, finding blog posts and even an "official" SAP Note, you identified the right interface: /SCWM/IF_API_WHR_OUTBOUND. Unfortunately, this is not yet listed as released or classic API. This would result in "warnings" in ATC and a classification as Level C ("Internal Objects" are used), although you did the best you can do. With Kernseife, you can now mark this SAP object as "recommended", which results in only "information" messages in ATC and leads to a "Level B" assessment of the custom code object / extension.

Based on these two examples, you can see: this is the power of a custom classification. You can overrule the SAP standard, be it because of timing (as you need the announced adjustments from the blog IMMEDIATELY) or scope (because SAP might not generally classify everything that you identify as "acceptable for your project" as "Classic API").

The possibility to "accept" usage of certain SAP objects will increase your governance quality, as your exemption approvers will not be flooded with hundreds of "false" exemption requests for objects that you generally accept in your project.

Advantage 2: Define and Enforce Custom Successors

While SAP is already delivering hundreds of the most important successor classifications (famous MARA -> I_Product), there might still be potential to guide your developers more precisely. Project Kernseife allows you to maintain a successor object in your classification, that will also be visible in the result of your ATC check - this makes it actionable for your developer!

 

Example 1: "Improve" Standard Successors

There are some more tables in the system, that have no successor mentioned officially, but where you can find (released!) CDS views as an alternative. To not flood you with details here, I simply refer to another blog based on the idea of @AndreasGraeber. But also for Function Modules or classes , there might be clear successors (e.g. not all READ_<table> might be having the successor information. There might be a lot of areas, where you want to decide in your project "don't use this, but use that!"

Example 2: Enforce and centralize Wrappers / custom successors

What happens if you create a wrapper for a standard SAP object, but your colleagues are not aware of it? They might re-create the same wrapper. With the possibility to also add Custom Objects (e.g. Z_WRAPPER_ABC) as a successor, you can also push your developers to harmonize the usage of wrappers.

Advantage 3: Enhance Dashboards for Measurement and Governance with consistent transparency

In several projects, we have already seen custom dashboards to track the current state of clean core. With the combination of the level concept and the "Technical Debt Score", you can assess systems and drill down into packages or even single objects.

Project Kernseife offers you direct access (e.g. with CDS-View ZKNSF_I_SCORING) to the data from ATC check runs to build these dashboards. You can use the Kernseife BTP Application to analyze your score - or create your own dashboard, for example with SAP Analytics Cloud, reflecting your custom rules to assign custom objects to business units (e.g. ZBR* is always Brasil).

The scoring is based on your configuration in the Kernseife classification, which allows you to own the definition of your clean core levels and deviate from SAP's standard definition - by this you own the definition of your clean core levels! To stick with the examples above, the usage of /SCWM/IF_API_WHR_OUTBOUND will impact your score in a limited way.

Advantage 4: Prioritize Your Cleanup Efforts with a "Potential Score"

After an analysis, you often face a daunting list of findings. The biggest challenge isn‚Äôt just identifying the issues, but knowing where to start the cleanup. This is where Kernseife's scoring mechanism becomes a powerful prioritization engine by providing two key metrics for each finding: a Score and a Potential Score.

  • The Score reflects the technical debt of the object as it exists today, based on your custom rules.
  • The Potential Score shows what the score would be if the developer refactored the code to use the defined successor.

Let's use our familiar example:

  • Your classification assigns a high "Technical Debt" Score of 10 for a direct SELECT on table MARA.
  • The officially released successor, I_Product, has a "clean" score of 0. Therefore, the finding's Potential Score is 0.

This creates a clear, quantifiable "improvement gap." An object with a Score of 10 and a Potential Score of 0 is a high-impact cleanup opportunity. In contrast, a finding with a Score of 2 and no defined successor (meaning its Potential Score is also 2) is a lower priority for immediate refactoring.

By sorting your findings based on the largest gap between the Score and Potential Score, you can instantly identify the "low-hanging fruits" and the refactoring tasks with the biggest impact. Let's be clear, this is just one piece of information, and maybe you shouldn't have any custom code in this area based on a process analysis, but I still believe it is important to have data to drive your decisions - and Project Kernseife offers you data for the technical insights.

Making the Right Choice: A Balanced Look at Both Approaches

Key Reasons to Adopt Project Kernseife

The main reason to use a Project Kernseife is typically the power of the custom classification (as the last chapter pointed out). You can adjust the classification of SAP objects based on your project reality and support your clean core journey with tailored data.

In addition, there might be a temporary, tactical benefit: As of today, Kernseife's dashboards can fill a gap until SAP's "Extensibility Deep Dive" dashboard is generally available. 

Important Considerations: When the Standard Approach is a Better Fit

At the same time, I want to be very clear: Project Kernseife is not needed in every company and project.

  • 1. The Need for Standard Alignment: If your primary goal is to align perfectly with SAP's out-of-the-box reporting and dashboards without deviation, the standard approach is more appropriate.
  • 2. The Responsibility of Power: Custom classification is powerful, but it requires ownership. Someone must define, document, and maintain these custom rules. This is an ongoing responsibility (and effort!), which you can spare yourself when you go with the standard solution, i.e. RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard.
  • 3. Implementation and Maintenance Overhead: While straightforward for experienced teams, implementing and maintaining any non-standard solution requires effort that must be planned for. It is ironically against the clean core imperative of leveraging "standard"!
  • 4. Unified Classification enables comparibility: Standardized classification leads to a comparability between different systems (e.g., you compare your central finance system with a peer system regarding the clean core level share), as the classification is the same for all systems.

Conclusion: Do you need to Take Control of Your Clean Core Strategy?

Project Kernseife is not for everyone. It is for organizations that find the standard clean core measurement too rigid and are ready to invest the effort to build a more nuanced, context-aware governance model. If you have the capacity and the architectural vision, it can transform your clean core initiative from a technical cleanup exercise into a strategic management of your system's extensibility.

Interested in more? Check out Project Kernseife: our open-source project where you can join the community, contribute, and support us with a GitHub star in the repository!

We recently concluded Supplier Connect Live 2025, an insightful digital event designed specifically for our SAP Business Network suppliers. If you missed it, it is worth taking the opportunity to catch up on everything that was discussed. Here‚Äôs a highlight reel of what to expect:

Key Takeaways:

  • AI-Driven Supplier Integration

Discover how SAP Business Network is leveraging AI to optimize processes like dispute resolution and onboarding. With the aim of implementing 400 AI use cases by 2026, AI and automation can significantly enhance interactions between suppliers and buyers.

  • Expanded Network Capabilities

Explore new offerings such as supply chain orchestration and comprehensive source-to-pay suites. 

Did you know the SAP Business Network migrated to the SAP Business Technology Platform?  This will bring a more solid foundation for future growth.

  • Enhanced Supplier Visibility

Learn how to optimize your profile and boost your discoverability and lead generation with advanced features.

With the Promote subscription, suppliers can access advanced features that enhance lead generation and optimize business opportunities.

  • Improved Account Management

Get tips on effective account management with new features like temporary accounts and domain block, along with recommendations for essential clean-up.  Preventing unwanted account proliferation and ensuring a cleaner directory for buyers benefits all.

  • Insights from an Experienced Supplier

Hear the fascinating fireside chat with Alexander Graff, Head of Corporate Business at Schweitzer Fachinformationen, who discussed the shift towards digitalization and emphasized the importance of building trust networks.

  • Future Developments Roadmap

Get a sneak peek into the roadmap for upcoming developments, targeting market reach, supplier profiles, and search capabilities, including the expansion of the supplier visibility to the whole SAP S/4 client base.  SAP is concentrating on entering new geographies and sectors while enhancing the supplier search experience to facilitate better connections and business opportunities.

Key Quote:

entry.title: Re: How to set route map in xml
entry.content:
You do not need to access any separate Route Map XML in Provisioning.

The custom role can be created directly in Admin Center ‚Üí Manage Route Maps.

No extra menu rights are required‚Äîjust ensure your jobRelType picklist and corresponding relationship (such as Second Manager or Compensation Planner) exist and are populated in EC.

In short: no need to chase XMLs ‚Äî just link your custom relationship to the route map, and let SuccessFactors do the magic.

For detailed step-by-step guidance, you can also check this SAP Community blog:
SAP SuccessFactors: Adding Custom Roles in Performance Route Map.

entry.title: Re: Price mismatch between two SAP systems in outline agr...
entry.content:
Dear Ravi,
Refer to the issue you shared, it seams like the SAP IDoc integration issue. My suggestion is to focus some key areas to investigate why the updated price from the PPC system isn't reflecting in the outline agreement in the regional SAP systems (AMS, APJ, EMEA):

1. IDoc Processing Status
Check the status of the IDoc in the receiving system (e.g., WE02 or WE05).
If the status is not ‚Äú53‚Äù (successfully posted), it means the IDoc was received but not processed correctly.
Look for error messages or warnings in the IDoc logs.

2. Function Module or Message Type Mapping
Confirm that the correct message type (e.g., ORDERS, CONTRACT, etc.) and function module are being used to update outline agreements.
If the function module doesn‚Äôt support price updates or is misconfigured, the update won‚Äôt reflect.

3. Change Pointers / ALE Configuration
Ensure change pointers are active for price changes in the PPC system.
Check if the distribution model (BD64) and partner profiles (WE20) are correctly set up for price updates.

4. Authorization Issues
The user or RFC destination used to post the IDoc might lack authorization to update outline agreements.
Check for authorization errors in the IDoc logs or ST22 dumps.

5. Custom Logic or User Exits
If there‚Äôs custom logic (e.g., in EXIT_SAPLEINM_002 or BADI implementations), it might be preventing the update.
Review any user exits or enhancements that could block or override the price update.

6. Outline Agreement Locking
If the outline agreement was locked during IDoc posting (e.g., someone was editing it), the update might have failed silently.
Check SM12 for lock entries.

7. Data Mapping Issues
Ensure the price field in the IDoc is correctly mapped to the outline agreement field.
Sometimes the IDoc contains the correct data, but it‚Äôs not mapped to the right field in the target system.

I suggest you to do the following steps mentioned below.

  1. Run transaction WE02/WE05 to check IDoc status and logs.
  2. Use BD87 to reprocess the IDoc manually and observe any errors. 
  3. Check SM13 for update failures.
  4. Review custom code or enhancements that might interfere.
  5. Validate partner profile and distribution model setup.
  6. Confirm that the outline agreement is not locked during posting.


Hope this will resolve the issue, if done please confirm

entry.title: How the Due Date and Reminder determined in task of Check Renewal Rules of customer contract?
entry.content:
How the Due Date is determined in task of Check Renewal Rules of customer contract?
And how Reminder days setting working in a contract?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How the Due Date and Reminder determined in task of C...
entry.content:
Dear Customer, 

Thank you for reaching out with your queries. I‚Äôm happy to provide clarification on both points you raised.  

1. **Determination of Due Date for the "Check Renewal Rules" Task**  
The Due Date for the BTM Task "Contract <Contract ID>, <Account> ends on <Contract End Date>." is maintained within the configuration settings of `Business Configuration Activity "Business Task Management for Contracts and Customer Returns` under Business Configuration - Overview. You can locate the active BTM Task titled "Contract <Contract ID>, <Account> ends on <Contract End Date>." The Due Date specified in this configuration determines the task Due Date.  

2. **Functionality of Reminder Days Setting in a Contract**  
The Reminder Days setting in a customer contract allows the system to automatically send a renewal task to the contract administrator prior to the contract's expiration. This task is triggered based on the number of days entered in the Reminder field. For instance, if you input 30 days, the system will notify the administrator 30 days before the contract ends. This notification enables the administrator to contact the customer for renewal or to discuss new terms.

For further details, you may refer to the help documents "Customer Contracts Quick Guide | SAP Help Portal" - https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_BUSINESS_BYDESIGN/2754875d2d2a403f95e58a41a9c7d6de/2de2bd93722d1014a5d3d77fa4f7f033.html?version=2508  and "Task ‚Äì Renew Customer Contract | SAP Help Portal." - https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_BUSINESS_BYDESIGN/2754875d2d2a403f95e58a41a9c7d6de/2ca71a4f722d1014aae6f79548936150.html?version=2508 

I hope this addresses your concerns effectively. Please feel free to reach out if you need further assistance or clarification.  

Best regards,  
Arjun T H 
SAP Product Support
